questions.uddipok: The graph shows the number of people living below the poverty line from 2005 to 2020. Describe graph. The number of people living below the poverty line

sub_questions.explanation: The given graph demonstates the percentage of people who are living below the poverty line from 2005 to 2020. The chart includes a comparative study of rural area and urban one. In 2005, 35% of people were living below the poverty line in rural area whereas it was 21% in urban one. Unfortunately, the number increased for both areas in 2010, when 45% were living below the poverty line in rural area and 30% in urban area. Then in 2015 the percentage with a little fall comes down to 32 and 25 for rural and urban area respectively. Additionally, the percentage went lower in 2020, 28% of people were living below poverty line in rural area and 20% in urban area. So, we learn from the chart that the living standard of the people were the lowest in 2010 as it had the largest number of f people living below the poverty line.

questions.uddipok:
The following is the beginning of a story. Complete it in your own words:–
It was a hot summer day. There was searching heat of the sun. On that day, a crow became very thirsty. It wanted to drink, but there was no water around it. So, it began to.....

sub_questions.explanation:
It was a hot summer day. There was scorching heat of the sun.  A crow became very thirsty. It wanted to drink water but there was no water around it. So, it began to fly but did not find any source of water anywhere.


The crow was very hopeful and patience. It was clever too. So, it did not lose heart and kept on flying. At last it found a jar in a garden. It became very pleased. It flew down and sat on the jar. But alas! There was a little water at the bottom of the jar and it was out of its reach. Hence, it tried to turn the jar over again and again but brought no result. After several efforts, the crow got tired and disappointed. In despair when it was about to leave the place, it noticed a heap of pebbles nearby. It got hope and hit upon a plan. The crow picked up some pebbles and started dropping into the jar one after another. As a result, the water of the jar rose up little by little. When the water came to the brim of the jar, the crow drank its heart content and flew away.


In this way, the strong will of the crow helped it to meet its thirst.

questions.uddipok: Suppose, you are Mushfiq/Musfiqa and your friend is Sharif/Sharifa. Now, write a letter to your friend telling him/her what she/he intends to do after the HSC examination and why.

sub_questions.explanation:
Subject: My Post-HSC Plans
Dear Sharif,
Hope this letter finds you well.
I'm writing to share my plans for after the HSC exams. I've been giving it a lot of thought and I'm excited about the possibilities that lie ahead.
After completing my HSC, I intend to pursue a degree in Computer Science. I've always been fascinated by technology and the endless possibilities it offers. I believe that a degree in Computer Science will equip me with the necessary skills to contribute to the field and pursue a fulfilling career.
The rapid advancements in technology have made it an exciting and dynamic field to be a part of. I'm particularly interested in exploring areas like artificial intelligence, machine learning, and software development. I envision myself working on innovative projects that have a positive impact on society.
Furthermore, a degree in Computer Science opens up a wide range of career opportunities. I could work in software development, IT consulting, data analysis, or even research. The possibilities are endless, and I'm eager to explore them all.
I'm confident that pursuing a degree in Computer Science will be a rewarding and fulfilling journey. I'm excited to embark on this new chapter in my life and see where it takes me.
I'd love to hear about your plans for after the HSC. What are you thinking of doing?
Best regards,
Mushfiq
Rajshahi, Bangladesh

questions.uddipok:
Summarize the following passage.
We spend money for different reasons. We buy foods, clothes or everyday essentials, pay for different services, entertain people, travel to places, help others in need or invest in business and thus spend money every day. In fact, spending is a part of our life.
Spending may make us happy or unhappy depending on how and why we spend. When we spend money on things that we need and within our limit, it is good. When it becomes a compulsive behaviour, it makes life stressful. Unnecessary spending or spending beyond one's means has some bad effects. For one thing, it may lead to financial ruin or debt, and for another,. it may create unhappiness within families. People who overspend are never satisfied with what they have. They always rush for brands, fashion items, designer clothes, etc. Over a period of time, it becomes an addiction which may eventually create psychological problems.
Nowadays, consumer items are displayed in stores or in advertisements in ways that they create a feeling of immediate need for them. We are constantly tempted to buy, use or consume things even when we do not have a genuine need. We all need to be careful here. Salespersons often encourage customers to buy things by flattering them. 'This is a perfect match for you,' they would say. or 'You look so stunning in that dress.' Never forget, they say the same thing to most of their customers. It is better not to be persuaded by such words. They use these words to please the customers as the more a customer buys, the higher the profit is. Overspending is not only related to shopping, it applies to other activities as well such as eating out. Many people buy too many items to eat in a restaurant. They can eat only some of them and the rest are wasted: It's not a responsible attitude. We cannot simply waste food because we have money to buy it.
Young people in a shopping mall often look at an item on display afd think 'Oh I must buy this. I really need this.' They may not have the money needed. In their wallet. So, they use credit cards but using them is like taking a loan. If they are not careful, the loans increase which might lead them to a debt-trap.
Sometimes children insist on buying things that their parents cannot pay without stretching their budget. This may happen because the children's friends also have them. It's not fair as it becomes a burden for the parents.
Finally, don't get trapped by the glossy advertisements on television or the Internet. You should rather ask yourself: "Do I need this?" The best way to control the habit of spending is not to think 'What I need', but 'Can I do without it?'

sub_questions.explanation: Money is spent every day for various reasons. Necessary expenses within our limit may make us happy. But unnecessary expenditure or spending money beyond our ability creates some problems and may lead to psychological problems. At present, consumer items are exhibited and advertised so attractively that we want to buy them immediately even without having a genuine need. Salespersons often flatter the customers to encourage them to buy more things. Buying more foods than requirements and their wastage means wastage of money. Children also make their parents fall in economic crisis by pressurizing them to buy unnecessary things. We should restrain this habit of overspending by asking ourselves if we can do without the thing we feel tempted to buy.

questions.uddipok:
Answer the following questions:
(a) What does WHO say about adolescence?
(b) How many adolescents are boys and how many are girls in Bangladesh?
(c) How is the condition of the adolescent girls in Bangladesh?
(d) What is the legal age of marriage for boys and girls in our country?
(e) When do the boys become ready for marriage?

sub_questions.explanation:
(a)
The World Health Organization (WHO) defines adolescence as the period of life between 10 and 19 years of age. This stage marks the transition from childhood to adulthood, characterized by significant physical, emotional, and social development. Adolescents experience rapid growth and undergo various changes that influence their health, behavior, and interactions with society.
(b)
According to the 2022 Bangladesh Census, the population of adolescents aged 10–14 is approximately 16.6 million, with 8.5 million boys and 7.8 million girls. For the 15–19 age group, there are about 16.5 million adolescents, comprising 8.1 million boys and 8.5 million girls. In total, adolescents make up about 28.8% of Bangladesh's population, with a near-equal distribution between boys and girls.
(c)
Adolescent girls in Bangladesh face several challenges
Child Marriage : Approximately 51% of girls in Bangladesh are married before the age of 18, making it one of the highest rates globally.
Education : While enrollment rates for girls have improved, many still face barriers to completing secondary education, especially in rural areas.
Health Risks : Early pregnancies pose significant health risks, with many adolescent girls becoming mothers before reaching adulthood.
Violence and Abuse : A significant number of adolescent girls experience physical or sexual violence, often within intimate relationships.
These issues hinder their development and access to opportunities, perpetuating cycles of poverty and inequality.
(d)
In Bangladesh, the legal age for marriage is 18 for girls and 21 for boys, as stipulated by the Child Marriage Restraint Act of 2017. However, the law includes provisions that allow for exceptions under certain circumstances, such as parental consent and court approval, which have been criticized for potentially undermining efforts to prevent child marriage.
(e)
While the legal age for marriage is 21 for boys in Bangladesh, readiness for marriage is influenced by various factors beyond age, including emotional maturity, financial stability, and societal expectations. Cultural norms often dictate that men should be established in their careers and capable of supporting a family before marriage. However, these expectations can vary widely across different communities and regions within the country.

questions.uddipok:
Rearrange the following sentences to make a coherent order.
(i) Next day all the servants submitted their sticks to the judge.
(ii) The judge also said that the stick of the thief would increase by an inch.
(iii) One stick was found shortened by an inch and the thief was easily detected and sent to jail thereby.
(iv) He made a complaint before the judge.
(v) He gave all of them a stick of equal length and asked to submit the stick on the following day.
(vi) He thought that the purse had been stolen by someone of his servants.
(vii) The judge summoned all the servants and all of them denied the charge.
(viii) One day a rich man lost his purse.
(ix) The judge then hit upon a plan to detect the thief.
(x) The servants went home and everyone kept his stick as it was but the servant who stole the purse reduced the length of his stick by one inch.

sub_questions.explanation:
(viii) →(vi)→ (iv) → (vii) → (ix)→ (v)→(ii)→(x) → (i) → (iii).
One day a rich man lost his purse. He thought that the purse had been stolen by someone of his servants. He made a complaint before the judge. The judge summoned all the servants and all of them denied the charge. The judge then hit upon a plan to detect the thief. He gave all of them a stick of equal length and asked to submit the stick on the following day. The judge also said that the stick of the thief would increase by an inch. The servants went home and everyone kept his stick as it was but the servant who stole the purse reduced the length length of his stick by one inch. Next day all the servants submitted their sticks to the judge. One stick was found shortened by an inch and the thief was easily detected and sent to jail thereby.
